tossups.question: This leader defeated a group of a thousand men under the command of Colonel David Synnot at the Siege of Wexford. John Lambert’s Instrument of Government helped codify the power of this figure, who presided over an argument against radicals in the Putney Debates.  Under the reign of this ruler, militias attempted to abolish stage plays and (*) Christmas traditions. This man and Thomas Fairfax led the New Model Army to a decisive victory at the Battle of Naseby against the Royalists. For ten points, name this Puritan who became Lord Protector after winning the English Civil War.

One character in this work wonders if the afterlife consists of a bathhouse full of spiders. The protagonist of this work claims that certain people, such as Napoleon, are extraordinary and can transgress moral laws. That man also has a troubling dream in which several drunkards beat a horse to death. The main character of this work gives money to support the family of (*) Marmeladov after he is killed in a carriage accident. In this work, Sonya urges the main character to admit to a certain action. For ten points, name this novel in which Raskolnikov kills a pawnbroker and her sister, a book by Fyodor Dostoevsky.

This is the final destination of souls in Inuit mythology. According to the Inca, it is ruled by Mama Quilla, the wife of Inti. In Aztec myth, this location is sometimes said to be a son of Tlaloc who had had a rabbit thrown at him by the other gods, which explains why it has a distinctive rabbit-shaped spot. (*) Chang’e is the Chinese goddess of this location. Pecos Bill’s horse once bucked Slue-Foot Sue so hard she landed on this object, and the trickster Coyote was fired from his stint as this object for spying on other animals from its position in the night sky. For ten points, name this only natural satellite of earth, the basis of lunar calendars.

It’s not Brazil, but this region’s Luquillo Mountains are home to a namesake Amazon parrot. A mix of islands and cays including Culebra and Vieques are located off the eastern coast of this island. An endemic species of frog known as coqui are located in this island’s El Yunque National Forest. This island’s central region is home to (*) Arecibo Observatory, one of the world’s largest radio telescopes. The successive 2017 natural disasters of Hurricane Irma and Maria damaged much of the infrastructure on this island. For ten points name this island territory of the United States, with capital San Juan.

One composer’s nineteenth piece in this genre opens with low, pulsing Cs as other instruments enter on A flat, E flat, and A, and is titled for the dissonance present in its opening. A piece in this genre is part of its composer’s “Russian” pieces of this type and is called “The Joke” due to several humorous devices within it. Six of these pieces by Mozart were dedicated to (*) Joseph Haydn [hidin]. Haydn himself wrote sixty-eight pieces in this genre, including “the Emperor,” leading him to be nicknamed the “father” of this genre. For ten points, name this genre that consists of two violins, a viola, and a cello.
tossups.answer: string quartets [accept Haydn string quartets or Mozart string quartets; prompt on quartet]
tossups.answer_formatted: string quartets [accept Haydn string quartets or Mozart string quartets; prompt on quartet]

tossups.question: The hydroxide of this element is used to remove carbon dioxide from life support systems during anesthesia. This element is found with copper in a Gilman reagent. This element is placed at the top of the activity series for single-displacement reactions. It’s not strontium, but the flame test of this element produces a bright (*) red color. Salts of this element are often used to treat bipolar disorder, and the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded for the advancements made in this element’s namesake “ion” batteries. For ten points, name this lightest alkali metal with atomic number 3 and symbol Li.

The first book of Theodore White’s series The Making of the Presidency chronicles this election. This election’s winning candidate was accused of appeasement by Edward Morgan for his calls to abandon the Quemoy and Matsu islands. A candidate during this election fulfilled his pledge to visit all fifty states despite a knee injury, and ran alongside (*) Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. One of this election’s candidates was harmed by his decision to refuse makeup during the first televised presidential debates. For ten points, name this election in which John F. Kennedy narrowly defeated Richard Nixon.

The presence of organisms in the genus Foraminifera may cause this substance to develop a pink hue. One structure composed of this material is convex facing the direction of the wind, and has two horns giving it a crescent shape. A white type of this material is composed of the calcium carbonate excrement of parrotfish, while another type in Hawaii is composed of (*) basalt and is colored black. This material is finer than gravel and coarser than silt. In arid areas, this material is primarily made of small particles of silica, or quartz. For ten points, name this material that makes up beaches and dunes in the desert.

It’s not France, but a novel primarily set in this country centers on the Irishman Darley's romance with the title Jewish woman, Justine. That novel is the first part of a quartet named for a city in this country written by Lawrence Durrell. In a novel set in this country, Amina shatters her collarbone when she is hit by a car. This country is the setting for a (*) trilogy that consists of the novels Palace Walk, Palace of Desire, and Sugar Street that features the family of the philandering patriarch al-Sayyid Ahmad. For ten points, name this country, which is the setting of the Alexandria Quartet and Naguib Mahfouz's Cairo Trilogy.

A pool boy in this movie is revealed to be gay when he clocks the main character’s shoes as being last season Prada. The main character of this movie says "Whoever said orange was the new pink was seriously disturbed" after introducing her Chihuahua, Bruiser. That main character helps the hairdresser Pauline get her dog back and teaches her the (*) “bend and snap.” This film’s protagonist clashes with Vivienne, the new girlfriend of her ex-boyfriend Warner, and it culminates with the trial of Brooke Wyndham. For ten points, name this movie starring Reese Witherspoon as UCLA sorority president Elle Woods, who goes to Harvard Law School.

In one play by this author, Henry’s name is changed from “Cain” after he murders his brother Abel. Later in that play, George becomes the president of the Fraternal Order of Mammals. In another one of this man’s plays, the hymn “Blessed Be the Tie That Binds” is performed in every act. In that play, the alcoholic choir director (*) Simon Stimson commits suicide and a girl revisits her twelfth birthday. This man wrote about the Antrobus family surviving through an ice age in one play, and wrote about Emily Webbs’ life and death in Grover's Corners in another. For ten points, name this American playwright of The Skin of Our Teeth and Our Town.

This man crushed a rebellion in the First Cheremis War, and gave land to the Stroganov family in return for their funding of territorial expansion. This man initiated a massacre after the defection of the Archbishop Pimen, and apocryphally blinded an architect so that he could never build anything more beautiful than (*) Saint Basil’s Cathedral. This man reorganized the military through the creation of the Streltsy infantry unit and the brutal Oprichniki secret police. The reign of this man’s incompetent son Fyodor led to the Time of Troubles. For ten points, name this Russian tsar known for his extreme cruelty.
tossups.answer: Ivan IV [or Ivan the Terrible or Ivan Grozny; prompt on Ivan]
tossups.answer_formatted: Ivan IV [or Ivan the Terrible or Ivan Grozny; prompt on Ivan]

tossups.question: In one of these works, a man leases a winepress to some workers, but they try to seize it for themselves. In another of these stories, a farmer scatters seeds on a footpath, on shallow soil, among weeds, and on fertile soil. One of these religious stories compares the Kingdom of Heaven to a (*) mustard seed, because mustard has a small seed but grows to be the largest plant in the garden. One these religious stories sees the prodigal son return to his father after spending away his inheritance. For ten points, name these metaphorical stories from the New Testament that illustrate points about Christianity.
tossups.answer: Parables of Jesus [both underlined parts needed; accept reasonable equivalents; prompt on parables by asking “by who?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Parables of Jesus [both underlined parts needed; accept reasonable equivalents; prompt on parables by asking “by who?]

tossups.question: A work in this genre created over twenty years after its subject’s death is housed in a library in West Branch, Iowa. Simmie Knox, who used a model in a blue dress to cast a shadow next to the subject in one of these works, became the first Black person to make one of these works. Another one of these works by the painter of Napoleon Leading the Army Over the Alps features the subject sitting in a chair in front of a (*) wall of flowers. The first one of these paintings was Gilbert Stuart’s Lansdowne Portrait. Kehinde Wiley painted the most recent of, for ten points, what official depictions of people like George Washington and Barack Obama?
tossups.answer: presidential portraits [accept paintings of presidents, prompt on portraits]
tossups.answer_formatted: presidential portraits [accept paintings of presidents, prompt on portraits]
acceptable: paintings of presidents, prompt on portraits

tossups.question: A poem by this author describes the “pallor of girls’ brows” and “the holy glimmer of goodbyes.” In another work of this poet, the speaker escapes “down some profound dull tunnel” and meets “the enemy he killed” in Hell. This author began one poem by asking “What passing-bells for those who die as cattle?” This author of (*) “Strange Meeting” wrote a poem in which "an ecstasy of fumbling" precedes one man “guttering, choking, drowning” “as under a green sea” due to a gas attack. For ten points, name this British World War I soldier and poet of “Anthem for Doomed Youth” and “Dulce et Decorum Est”.

Vesicle fusion in these cells are mediated by complexes containing VAMP1 and VAMP2, which are examples of SNARE proteins. Applying silver nitrate to a formaldehyde mixture of these cells can stain them for microscopy in a “black reaction” named for Golgi. Naked mole rats were found to lack Substance P, which is a peptide secreted by these cells to induce nociception. The lipid (*) myelin increases the rate of action potentials on the membranes of these cells. Dendrites at the end of these cells transmit and receive electrical signals across synapses. For ten points, name these cells, the basic units of the nervous system.

Though it’s not The Marriage of Figaro, one character in this opera complains that he is tired of hearing the aria “non piu andrai.” The protagonist of this opera sings “La ci darem la mano” [la chee dar-EM la mahno] to try and seduce his love interest Zerlina. This opera’s main character describes his plans for an upcoming party in the (*) “Champagne Aria.” The title character’s servant Leporello relates the many exploits of his master to Donna Elvira in this opera’s “Catalogue Aria.” A statue of the Commendatore drags the title character to Hell at the end of, for ten points, what Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart opera depicting a legendary Spanish seducer?
tossups.answer: Don Giovanni [do not accept or prompt on “Don Juan”]
tossups.answer_formatted: Don Giovanni [do not accept or prompt on "Don Juan"]

tossups.question: Jacques Derrida coined the term “hauntology” in a 1993 work whose title alludes to this work. This work notes how the discovery of America and the rounding of the Cape caused the demise of feudalism. A ten-point list in the middle of this work calls for the abolition of inheritance and centralization of credit. The preamble to this work declares that (*) Metternich and Guizot have created a “holy alliance to exorcise” a “spectre” of the title concept that has been “haunting Europe.” For ten points, name this pamphlet written by Frederich Engels and Karl Marx.
tossups.answer: The Communist Manifesto [Editor’s note: the Derrida work is Spectres of Marx.]
tossups.answer_formatted: The Communist Manifesto [Editor’s note: the Derrida work is Spectres of Marx.]

tossups.question: A consequence of this phenomenon was observed during the 1919 solar eclipse in the Eddington experiment. A pair of 4-mile-long interferometers are used to detect oscillations caused by this phenomenon. The effect of this phenomenon on light waves can cause multiple images of distant objects to appear in its namesake (*) lensing. Two lead spheres were placed on either side of a torsion balance during Henry Cavendish’s experiment to find the constant associated with this phenomenon. The emission of waves associated with this phenomenon is searched for by the LIGO project. For ten points, name this force discovered by Isaac Newton that attracts objects with mass together.
tossups.answer: gravity [accept gravitational waves or gravitational force or gravitational lensing; prompt on general relativity before “pair” with “what phenomenon does that describe?”]
tossups.answer_formatted: gravity [accept gravitational waves or gravitational force or gravitational lensing; prompt on general relativity before “pair” with “what phenomenon does that describe?]

tossups.question: The development of IR8 was an important breakthrough during an event named for this color, which was aided by Norman Borlaug’s contributions. This color appears in the title of a philosophical work that discusses its author’s “Third International Theory.” A militia with this color in its name resisted New York’s attempts to control (*) Vermont, played a decisive role in the battle of Ticonderoga, and was led by Ethan Allen. A 20th century “Revolution” named for this color that massively increased the world’s agricultural output. For ten points, name this color that names a number of modern pro-environmental parties.
tossups.answer: green [accept The Green Book, accept Green Party]

tossups.question: An unsolved problem in Yang-Mills theory concerns a “gap” named for this quantity. An imaginary value for this quantity defines a tachyonic field, which mediates particles that travel faster than light. The “reduced” form of this quantity is equal to the reciprocal of the sum of the reciprocals of this quantity for two objects. Einstein hypothesized the equivalence between the (*) inertial and gravitational forms of this quantity. By Newton’s law, the gravitational force between two objects is proportional to this non-distance quantity for the two objects. For ten points, name this quantity measured in kilograms.
tossups.answer: mass [accept mass gap or imaginary mass or reduced mass or inertial mass or gravitational mass]
tossups.answer_formatted: mass [accept mass gap or imaginary mass or reduced mass or inertial mass or gravitational mass]

bonuses.leadin: In this story, a former employee of the Dead Letter Office works in a Wall Street office with Nippers, Ginger Nut, and Turkey. For ten points each,
parts: Name this story whose title character responds to everything with “I would prefer not to." He later dies of starvation after preferring not to eat while in prison for vagrancy.

This author of “Bartleby, the Scrivener” wrote other short stories in his collection “The Piazza Tales.” He also wrote a novel where Ahab goes on a mad crusade to find the title white whale, Moby Dick.
This other short story by Melville features Amasa Delano’s visit to the ship the San Dominick, where unbeknownst to him, a slave revolt has taken place that has overthrown the title captain.

bonuses.leadin: This character names her son “Sorrow” but says that she will change his name to “Joy” upon her husband’s return. For ten points each:
answers: Cio-Cio-San [cho-cho-sahn] [accept Madame Butterfly or Madama Butterfly]
parts: Name this woman who sings the aria “Un bel di, vedremo” as she ignores the advice of her maid Suzuki and waits for her husband to return. This character had earlier admitted that she had converted to Christianity in anticipation of marrying an American.

This American naval officer marries Cio-Cio-San with the intention of leaving her due to Japan’s lax divorce laws. After returning with his new wife Kate, this character is too ashamed to face Cio-Cio, causing her to commit suicide.
Cio-Cio-San and Pinkerton feature in Madama Butterfly, an opera by this composer. The title woman stabs Baron Scarpia at the end of the third act of Tosca, another opera by this composer.
acceptable: Cio-Cio-San [accept Madame Butterfly or Madama Butterfly]
Cio-Cio-San [accept Madame Butterfly or Madama Butterfly]

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about history in the Indian Ocean:
answers: [10] The Sentinelese people inhabit North Sentinel Island, which is found on the eastern edge of this bay. This bay shares its name with the Indian state with capital Kolkata and a species of tiger. ANSWER: Bay of Bengal
Tamil people [accept Tamilar or Thamizhar; accept Tamil Tigers]
parts: The Sentinelese people inhabit North Sentinel Island, which is found on the eastern edge of this bay. This bay shares its name with the Indian state with capital Kolkata and a species of tiger.

This Chinese dynasty used Indian Ocean trade routes to acquire vast amounts of wealth. This dynasty sent Zheng He on trading expeditions across the Indian Ocean, traveling as far as the Horn of Africa and bringing back numerous exotic animals.

People of this ethnicity likely traded across the Indian Ocean with the Roman Empire at sites like Muziris and Arikamedu. A group of people with this ethnicity surrendered in May 2009, ending a 25 year civil war.
answers_formatted: The Sentinelese people inhabit North Sentinel Island, which is found on the eastern edge of this bay. This bay shares its name with the Indian state with capital Kolkata and a species of tiger. ANSWER: Bay of Bengal [10]
acceptable: The Sentinelese people inhabit North Sentinel Island, which is found on the eastern edge of this bay. This bay shares its name with the Indian state with capital Kolkata and a species of tiger. ANSWER: Bay of Bengal

Sentinelese people inhabit North Sentinel Island, which is found on the eastern edge of this bay. This bay shares its name with the Indian state with capital Kolkata and a species of tiger. ANSWER: Bay of Bengal

bonuses.leadin: The US Bureau of Labor Statistics found that industrial and organizational psychology will be the fastest growing occupation over the next decade. For ten points each:
parts: IO psychologists are concerned with this action, which is an incessant pattern of mistreatment of others leading to emotional or physical harm. Through social media, workers can face the “cyber” form of this concept.

Lewis Terman, who worked at this university, revised an intelligence test developed by Alfred Binet to assess troops during World War I. Another experiment conducted at this university was analyzed in The Lucifer Effect.

To understand workplace relationships, psychologists French and Raven conducted a notable study of this concept, dividing it into five distinct forms. Joseph Nye distinguished between “soft” and “hard” varieties of this concept.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about the compound xanthine:
parts: Xanthine is synthesized from this compound that, when methylated, forms the 5-prime cap of messenger RNA. This nitrogenous base pairs with cytosine in DNA and RNA.
Guanine is converted to xanthine through deamination, which replaces an amine group with this other functional group. The side chain of serine contains this functional group attached to a carbon.
Along with adenine, guanine and xanthine are examples of this type of organic compound that consists of two fused rings. These compounds are contrasted with pyrimidines.

bonuses.leadin: If there’s one thing rulers like doing, it’s giving orders. For ten points each, answer some questions about famous edicts from history:
parts: After witnessing the bloody Kalinga Wars, this grandson of Chandragupta converted to Buddhism and issued the Rock Edicts to espouse his newfound morals.

Louis XIV revoked protections for Huguenots in the Edict of Fontainebleau, and full religious freedom would not come until the signing of The Declaration of the Rights of Man and Citizen during this tumultuous period that saw the storming of the Bastille.
After early Catholic success during the Thirty Years’ War, Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II passed this edict attempting to restore the religious situation agreed to in the Peace of Augsburg.

bonuses.leadin: The Hamiltonian is defined as the sum of potential energy and this quantity. For ten points each:
answers: coefficient of restitution [or COR; prompt on e]
parts: Name this type of energy possessed by an object in motion. The amount of this type of energy can be calculated as one-half mass times velocity squared.
A collision that conserves kinetic energy is described by this term. In this type of collision, the relative velocity between the two objects remains the same.

For an elastic collision, this quantity is equal to one, and it is zero for a perfectly inelastic collision. This quantity is calculated as the ratio between the relative velocities between the two objects after and before the collision.

bonuses.leadin: The jurisdiction of holders of this title is known as the Holy See. For ten points each:
answers: Pope [accept Supreme Pontiff or Pontifex Maximus or Roman Pontiff or bishop of Rome]
parts: Name this position, the holder of which is the head of the Catholic Church. This title is currently held by Francis I.
According to this belief of the Catholic Church, doctrines defined by the pope are inherently correct and irreformable because they are given with the help of the Holy Spirit.
New popes are elected by a College of these leading bishops, who are appointed by the Pope for life. Currently, there are 223 of these people in the Catholic Church.
answers_formatted: Pope [accept Supreme Pontiff or Pontifex Maximus or Roman Pontiff or bishop of Rome]

bonuses.leadin: In one work, this artist depicted a man wearing red and barefoot while pointing at a symbolic lamb. For ten points each:
answers: Raphael [or Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino; accept Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood]
parts: Name this artist of St. John the Baptist in the Wilderness. Another of this artist’s works is a triptych whose sections include Death and the Miser and The Wayfarer.

A young John the Baptist carrying a pan of water is depicted in Christ in the House of His Parents by John Everett Millais, who was part of a school named for being opposed to this Renaissance artist. This artist depicted many famous ancient Greeks in his The School of Athens.

Both Caravaggio and Artemisia Gentileschi depicted the death of John the Baptist in paintings titled [this woman] with the Head of John the Baptist. Gustave Moreau painted this woman over 150 times, including one in which she dances in front of her stepfather Herod.

bonuses.leadin: Cantastoria is a form of visual storytelling in which these objects are used as aids. For ten points each:
parts: Name these objects which form the basis of Bunraku and Punch and Judy theatre. “Sock” and “finger” varieties of these objects have been used in a variety of children’s literature.

In Japan, some puppets were used to perform a “love” variety of this action in plays titled for it at “Amijima” and “Sonezaki.” A ritualistic variety of this action known as seppuku is depicted in some Japanese literature.

The aforementioned plays The Love Suicides at Amijima and The Love Suicides at Sonezaki were written by this Japanese bunraku playwright, who also wrote about Yohei outbidding Hisosuke for the prostitute Azuma’s freedom in The Uprooted Pine.

bonuses.leadin: The “Gaussian” type of this value measures it for two-dimensional surfaces. For ten points each:
parts: Name this intrinsic value symbolized kappa that, for a circle, is equal to one over its radius. Hyperbolic geometries have a negative value for this value.
Curvature is defined as the magnitude of the derivative of the unit tangent vector with respect to this quantity. The distance traveled between two points along a curve is given by this quantity.

The curvature of a line has this value because its unit tangent vector is constant at all points, and thus its derivative has this value. This value of curvature is also associated with flat surfaces.

bonuses.leadin: Protestors attempted to block access to this site ahead of a 2020 speech. For ten points each:
answers: Lakota [accept Lakota Sioux or Teton Sioux, prompt on Sioux]
Standing Rock Indian Reservation [accept Inyan Woslal Han]
parts: Name this site where President Donald Trump delivered a speech for the Fourth of July. This site in South Dakota consists of the heads of four former Presidents sculpted into the side of a mountain.
Many of the protestors were people from this Native American tribe that controls the area of the Black Hills that contains Mount Rushmore according to the Treaty of Fort Laramie.

Some council fires of the Lakota were forced onto this reservation. Over the past few years, hundreds of indigenous activists have been killed or arrested in this location while protesting against the Dakota Access Pipeline.
answers_formatted: Lakota [accept Lakota Sioux or Teton Sioux, prompt on Sioux]

bonuses.leadin: This molecule can be synthesized by the hydrogenation of benzene over a nickel or platinum catalyst. For ten points each:
answers: boat conformation [do not accept or prompt on “twist boat conformation”]
parts: Name this ring-shaped alkane with formula C6H12 [C-six-H-twelve]. In its most stable “chair” configuration, the hydrogen atoms of this molecule are labeled as axial or equatorial.
Because it is an alkane, cyclohexane is composed of hydrogen and this element, which forms the basis of organic chemistry. This element has atomic number 6.

Cyclohexane can exist in the chair conformation or this other conformation. This conformation of cyclohexane is unstable due to steric hindrance from its flagpole hydrogens, which is resolved by twisting this conformation.
answers_formatted: boat conformation [do not accept or prompt on "twist boat conformation"]

bonuses.leadin: California has played an integral role in 20th century electoral history. For ten points each:
parts: Before defeating Jimmy Carter in the election of 1980, this politician served as governor of California from 1967 to 1975. This man’s vice president George H.W. Bush criticized this man’s namesake economic policy as “voodoo economics.”

This longtime leading progressive and California senator served as Theodore Roosevelt’s running mate in the 1912 Presidential Election and introduced reforms such as railroad commissions and recall elections.

This California governor unsuccessfully sought the 1952 Republican nomination for President. He was named Supreme Court Chief Justice and presided over landmark cases such as Brown v. Board and Miranda v. Arizona.

bonuses.leadin: One of these pieces named for Pope Marcellus apocryphally convinced the Council of Trent not to ban polyphonic music. For ten points each:
answers: Pope Gregory I [or Saint Gregory the Great; accept Gregorian chants]
parts: Name these religious choral works that often incorporate liturgical texts set to music. These works include sections called “Kyrie,” “Gloria,” and “Agnus Dei.”
This Renaissance Italian composer wrote the Pope Marcellus Mass for the Council of Trent. This composer collected several of his motets in the collection Canticum Canticorum, or Song of Songs.
Prior to Palestrina’s composition of the Pope Marcellus Mass, liturgical music was mostly in the form of monophonic ‘chants’ named for this pope.
answers_formatted: Pope Gregory I [or Saint Gregory the Great; accept Gregorian chants]

bonuses.leadin: In a scene from a play from this era, Mirabell and Millamant discuss their potential wedding. For ten points each:
parts: Identify this era, during which playwrights such as Aphra Behn, William Congreve, and William Wycherley produced its namesake “comedies.” It is named for the sponsorship of theatrical productions after the return of Charles II to the English throne.
Congreve’s The Way of the World begins at a chocolate house in this city. Many Restoration comedies were produced at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in this capital of England.
This earlier English playwright and contemporary of William Shakespeare influenced many Restoration authors. He is known for comedies such as The Alchemist and Volpone.

bonuses.leadin: Cu Chulainn received his name after killing one of these animals belonging to Culann. For ten points each:
parts: Cu Chulainn also has a taboo against eating these animals, and is weakened before the Cattle Raid at Cooley because he eats the meat of this type of animal.
Cu Chulainn was killed after Lugaid spilled his innards with one of these weapons. The warrior woman Scathach taught Cu Chulainn how to use a barbed weapon of this type called Gae Bulg.

The story of Cu Chulainn appears in the Ulster Cycle, a mythological cycle from this island, which is partially controlled by Britain. Saint Patrick supposedly banished all the snakes from this island.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer these questions about Mesopotamia’s earliest civilization, Sumer:
answers: Sargon of Akkad [accept Sargon the Great or Sargon I]
parts: Sumer was located in the “Fertile Crescent” between the Tigris River and this river. This longest West Asian river begins in Turkey and empties into the Persian Gulf.
This Akkadian conqueror of Sumer is said to have founded the world’s first empire. This king’s daughter Enheduanna is the first recorded poet in history.
Before its ultimate collapse, Sumer experienced a renaissance during the Third Dynasty of this city, which saw the writing of the Epic of Gilgamesh. This city was home to the Great Ziggurat.
answers_formatted: Sargon of Akkad [accept Sargon the Great or Sargon I]

bonuses.leadin: In 2018, this YouTube duo met with violinist Ray Chen to produce several videos mocking his very first rendition of Mendelssohn’s Violin Concerto No.1. For ten points each:
parts: Name this channel that features violinists Eddy Chen and Brett Yang. Their recent popularity has been credited as one way “the 2010s have changed music forever.”
TwoSet Violin is based in this country, where both Brett and Eddy have played in professional orchestras. This nation famously contains a building with sail-like qualities located in Sydney.
In many of their videos, TwoSet Violin references this fictional character. This caricature of the perfect student supposedly practices 40 hours a day and is a virtuoso at every instrument.

bonuses.leadin: This character begins the work in which he appears by saying “Maman died today.” For ten points each:
parts: Name this dreary, emotionless protagonist who is eventually put on trial for murdering an Arab on a beach in The Stranger.
This French-Algerian author depicted Meursault in his novel The Stranger. This author also wrote about an illness in the town of Oran in his novel The Plague.

This character asks Mersault if he loves her, to which he responds that love doesn’t mean anything and that he doesn’t think he does. This girlfriend of Meursault goes to a Fernandel film with him and cries after he is sentenced to death.
